data.text:
Dipping a piece of baguette in it imparts a delightful taste to the bread. I am, of course, referring to olive oil.

I discovered I like to dip crusty bread in the stuff at a fine restaurant a few years ago and now I prefer it to butter — except on cinnamon rolls.

I’ve been curious about the various grades of the product so I decided to do a little research.

First, let’s dispel that myth regarding “Extra Virgin” and “Virgin Olive Oil.” The name has nothing to do with the individual doing the processing.

The olives used for pressing into olive oil are much smaller than those used for pickling (people or martinis). One hundred pounds of these olives are required to produce about 15 pounds of olive oil.

The first pressing of the little rascals yields what is known as “virgin oil.” However, the first pressing of the highest quality hand-picked olives yields that “Extra Virgin Oil” (an interesting choice of words).

These olives were washed, blended, mashed and squeezed in a hydraulic press at room temperature.

This liquid is then put through a centrifuge to draw out the water.

The oil must pass tests for flavor, color and aroma and must contain less than 1 percent of oleic acid, which affects its flavor.

This oil is typically green and redolent of olives. Most of the extra virgin olive oils are imported from Italy or France.

“Fine virgin oil” comes from the second pressing of the same olives. It’s good but doesn’t make the cut to be extra virgin.

“Pure oil” is extracted from whatever is left in the press after the second pressing. This stuff is basically colorless and flavorless and usually has a little extra virgin thrown in to give it an olive flavor.

“Light oil” is similar to pure oil without the addition of the extra virgin oil. It’s produced especially for the U.S. market.

Choose your olive oil carefully and store it in a cool, dark place. The good stuff, properly stored, will last about two years.

Good olive oil is more expensive than other vegetable oils so use the good stuff in salad dressings and use the cheaper stuff for cooking purposes.

Oh, by the way, good bread is best for the dipping.
